Table 2 Catalysts O species Ce species Cu species Mn species OA/OL Ce3+/Ce4+ Cu+/Cu2+ Mn2+/Mn Mn3+/Mn Mn4+/Mn CuMn/Ce 0.29 0.15 0.53 0.37 0.22 0.41 CuMnLa/Ce 0.35 0.16 0.50 0.11 0.44 0.46 CuMnSm/Ce 0.67 0.19 0.52 0.14 0.61 0.25 CuMnHo/Ce 0.65 0.18 0.55 0.27 0.63 0.09 Inhibition of CO oxidation over Cu-Mn-Ce-O composite catalyst in the presence of dry powder fire extinguishing agent: Mechanism investigation and mitigation strategy Ning Kang Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Jin Lin Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Shouxiang Lu Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Zhiqiang Zhao Investigation Writing – review & editing Xiaoyang Yu Writing – review & editing State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China, 96 Jinzhai Road, Hefei, Anhui 230026, China State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China 96 Jinzhai Road Hefei Anhui 230026 China State Key Laboratory of Fire Science, University of Science and Technology of China, 96 Jinzhai Road, Hefei, Anhui, 230026, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. The effects of typical dry powder fire extinguishing agents (DPFEA) on the CO oxidation catalysts were carried out. Cu-Mn-Ce-O composite catalyst (CuMn/Ce) for CO oxidation in loose contact with two typical components of DPFEA (NH4H2PO4 and NaHCO3) was tested to evaluate the performance of CO removal. The CO catalytic activities mixed by NaHCO3 are worse than those mixed by NH4H2PO4 at the same mixing ratios, which may be caused by the lower temperature range of NaHCO3 decomposition and the masked catalyst surfaces by CO2 and H2O released by NaHCO3. Further, the NaHCO3 resistance approach was proposed by introducing rare earth metal dopants (La, Sm and Ho) or coupling an alkaline sorbent (LiOH). Among all rare earth metal dopants, Sm is most appropriate for enhanced NaHCO3 resistance of CuMn/Ce catalyst. And 20 wt% LiOH-CuMn/Ce shows the best capacity for NaHCO3 resistance, as evidenced by the excellent CO catalytic performance similar to pure CuMn/Ce. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO removal Cu-Mn-Ce-O composite catalyst Dry powder fire extinguishing agent Rare earth metal Alkaline sorbent Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The increasing demand for the safety of industrial processes and the protection of the environment lead to attention to pollution control, especially in confined working spaces with poor ventilation [1,2]. The electric cables and fuel pipes necessarily required for operation are combustible, and they may be ignited by heat or fire source to release fire smoke which raises higher requirements for closed-loop air revitalization. CO is one of the main air pollutants that must be removed by active control techniques [3] as well as the most common hazardous component of fire smoke [4]. It is worth noting that the confined space pollution control system will face the vast challenges of residual fire extinguishing agents (FEAs) diffusing into the fire smoke, driven by airflow, and then participating in the CO elimination process. Thus, it is important to evaluate the effect of FEAs on CO removal. Catalytic combustion is a practical and efficient way to CO removal, with the aid of catalysts promising catalytic activity for CO oxidation [5]. Recently, base metal oxides present the advantages of low cost and good catalytic performance [6,7]. Hopcalite catalysts composed of manganese dioxide and copper oxide have been applied for commercial purposes, and many efforts have been devoted to improving their catalytic activity at low temperature and poison resistance [8]. To improve the catalytic activities, non-noble metals such as Co [9], Fe [10], Ce, Cr and Ni [11] were generally selected as the promoter or support to incorporate into the Hopcalite catalysts. Previous works indicated that the type of promoters had a great influence on the specific surface area, particle size, and active site distribution of catalysts, which could affect the catalytic activity for CO oxidation. In the aforementioned promoters, CeO2 has unique advantages for Cu–Mn composite oxides catalyst to reduce the temperatures taken by CO complete oxidation. Lin et al. [12] prepared Cu-Mn-Ce-O composite catalysts and reported the Cu-Mn-Ce-O with Cu/Mn mass ratio (1/1) exhibited the highest catalytic oxidation of CO. Additionally, it has been proposed that the excellent catalytic activity of the Cu–Mn-Ce-O catalysts was dependent on the good dispersion of copper manganese oxides species, the dual synergistic effects in the interfaces of CuO-MnO2 and CuO-CeO2, and the increased number of lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancies [13,14]. However, the classical non-noble metal catalysts usually became deactivated in contact with impurities like water vapor and SO2, disturbing the stability of these catalysts [15,16]. The effect of H2O or SO2 on catalytic activity and the approaches to the enhanced H2O or SO2 resistance have attracted much attention previously. The dry powder fire extinguishing agent (DPFEA) made mainly of ammonium phosphate (NH4H2PO4) or sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) is widely used [17] in the fire engineering field, which may be continuously diffused with the airflow once the air purification system starts working [18]. Hence, DPFEA is also a potential impurity in terms of the catalytic process of CO oxidation. Although few studies have investigated the poisoning mechanism of catalysts by CO2 [19] or phosphorus [20,21] related to NaHCO3 or NH4H2PO4, the understanding of the role of DPFEA particles in the deactivation mechanism of CO oxidation catalysts is still primitive and the approach to address catalyst deactivation in the presence of DPFEA remains unclear. Therefore, it is necessary to make some progress in understanding the effect in the presence of DPFEA and enhancing tolerance to DPFEA for the case of significant inhibition. In the present work, the supported Cu-Mn-Ce-O catalyst synthesized through the wet impregnation method was tested for CO removal in loose contact with DPFEA using a fixed bed reactor. NH4H2PO4 and NaHCO3 were representative for studying the relationship between Cu-Mn-Ce-O catalyst and DPFEA. The approach to improve the DPFEA resistance was proposed, which involved introducing the rare earth metal dopants (R=La, Sm and Ho) or coupling an alkaline sorbent (LiOH) based on Cu-Mn-Ce-O catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The synthesis of the Cu-Mn-Ce-O catalyst was reported previously [12]. An adequate amount of aqueous copper acetate (Cu(Ac)2⋅H2O, 99.0%) and manganese acetate (Mn(Ac)2⋅4 H2O, 99.0%) solutions were prepared and used to impregnate the corresponding metals over nanostructured CeO2 (50 nm, 99.5%) as the support, where the contents of copper and manganese element were both 7 wt%. After stirring for 4 h at room temperature, the mixture was subsequently dried at 358 K overnight and calcined at 633 K for 3 h. The obtained material was denoted as CuMn/Ce. The rare earth metal (R=La, Sm or Ho)-doped Cu-Mn-Ce-O catalysts were prepared under similar procedures of CuMn/Ce. Differently, the required amount of La, Sm, or Ho precursors (La(Ac)3⋅1.5 H2O, 99.9%, Sm(Ac)3⋅6 H2O, 99.0% or Ho(Ac)3⋅6 H2O, 99.9%) was added to the aqueous copper acetate and manganese acetate solutions, where mole ratio of rare earth metal acetate to copper and manganese acetate was 1. The final samples were designated as CuMnLa/Ce, CuMnSm/Ce and CuMnHo/Ce. A certain amount of LiOH·H2O was weighed, mechanically admixed with as-prepared CuMn/Ce, and grind to achieve good reagent homogeneity [22]. The powder mixture was then heated at 200 °C for 1 h and labeled as xLiOH-CuMn/Ce, where “x” was the nominal weight percentage of lithium hydroxide from 10% to 70%. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) investigation was done on a diffractometer (MiniFlex 300/600) using Cu-Kα radiation at 40 kV and 15 mA in a 2θ range from 10° to 80° with a scanning step of 0.02°. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption analysis was performed at 77 K by an automatic surface area and porosity analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2460) to measure the specific surface area and pore size distribution of the pure catalysts. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB250Xi spectrometer with an excitation source of monochromatized Al Ka (hv = 1486.6 eV) and a pass energy of 30 eV. And the values of binding energies were calibrated with the C1s peak of contaminant carbon at 284.80 eV. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out to test the reduction temperature of catalysts via an automatic chemical adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics AutoChem II2920). The morphological structures and elemental compositions of pure catalysts and the products after the DPFEA mixing test were investigated by a ZEISS GeminiSEM 500 field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) coupled with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement As shown in Fig. 1, CO oxidation activities of pure catalysts were tested in a fixed bed reactor (inner diameter = 6.00 mm, height = 0.30 m) equipped with an infrared CO and CO2 gas analyzer, using 0.25 g of new catalysts with the particle size of 0.15–0.30 mm. All samples were pretreated under airflow for 1 h at 200 °C. The experiments were carried out under 0.4% CO and balanced air at a total gas flow rate of 300 mL min−1, where the samples were heated from 30 °C to 180 °C at a certain heating rate. Besides, 0.25 g catalyst was uniformly mixed with dry powder (NaHCO3 or NH4H2PO4 as the model reactant) by using a spoon for 5 min to carry out dry powder mixing test and measure the effect of catalyst/dry powder mass ratio (5/1, 5/3, 5/5 and 5/7) and heating rate (3, 6, 10 and 15 °C/min) on catalytic performance. The capacities of resisting NaHCO3 for CO oxidation of CuMnR/Ce or xLiOH-CuMn/Ce catalysts were evaluated, where the catalyst/NaHCO3 mass ratio was kept at 5/1. The reacting atmosphere and temperature were consistent with those of the above experiment on catalytic activity measurement for CO oxidation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of pure catalysts XRD patterns of CuMn/Ce and various CuMnR/Ce catalysts are shown in Fig. 2a. All the catalysts exhibit seven repeatable diffraction peaks corresponding to cubic fluorite-structured ceria (JCPDS, No. 34–0394), while no diffraction peaks of manganese are found, which suggests that the Mn species are in the form of amorphous oxides or microcrystals [23]. The CuMn/Ce catalyst shows the characteristic peaks for bulk Cu2O (JCPDS, No. 05–0667) [12]. However, the diffraction peaks of copper become weaker and even disappear in CuMnR/Ce due to the significant reduction and high dispersion of Cu species over the support surfaces [23]. Neither XRD of R/Ce used for a reference nor CuMnR/Ce shows peaks of rare earth metal, indicating the R-Ce solid solutions are formed [24]. To further reveal the textural properties of the samples, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of all catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2b, c. The type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops suggest that all catalysts are typical mesoporous materials [25]. The CuMnR/Ce catalysts concentrate on the larger pore size (20 nm), as evidenced by the pore size distributions (Fig. 2c). The differences in pore size of CuMn/Ce and CuMnR/Ce are connected with the defects in their structure contributed by Ce and R promoters. Another peak dV/dlogD for CuMnLa/Ce is located around 5 nm, which indicates that La dopant makes pore structures of ceria-supported bimetallic Cu–Mn oxides catalysts more disordered. The textural parameters of the different catalysts are listed in Table 1. CuMnR/Ce catalyst exhibits higher BET specific surface areas, following the order CuMnLa/Ce (38.3 m2/g) >CuMnSm/Ce (33.2 m2/g) >CuMnHo/Ce (30.6 m2/g). It might be caused by the addition of rare earth dopants or the loading of Cu and Mn, which requires further analysis. The pore features of all catalysts are almost invariable, showing that these catalysts retained a similar pore structure of CeO2 support [26]. Amongst, the pore diameter of CuMnSm/Ce or CuMnHo/Ce is similar to that of CuMn/Ce, but the CuMnLa/Ce possesses a slightly smaller pore diameter, which might be led by pore blocking by the metal particles [27]. The surface morphologies of the different catalysts are presented in Fig. 2d-g. The spherically shaped CuMn/Ce consists of aggregates of Cu, Mn and Ce oxides crystallites, where Cu–Mn oxide grains distribute on the surface of ceria support. Compared to CuMn/Ce, the larger agglomerate of the Cu phase and Mn phase over the support in CuMnLa/Ce. Besides, a minor amount of individual copper oxide particles can be observed, which are easily distinguished from the loading species. It can be also noted that the whole of CuMnSm/Ce or CuMnHo/Ce is fluffy and porous in agreement with the above results of textural parameters. And their surfaces are rougher to offer the more active sites, promoting gas adsorption on the material surface. Therefore, the La dopant may disturb the distribution of active species and the interaction between copper and manganese. XPS spectra and high-resolution XPS spectra of Ce 3d, Cu 2p, Mn 2p and O 1s are displayed in Fig. 3 to investigate the chemical states and surface compositions. The surface compositions of O, Ce, Cu and Mn species calculated by the relative peak areas are listed in Table 2. Ce 3d spectra were classified into ten peaks in Fig. 3a. Ten major peaks imply Ce4+ and Ce3+ are major chemical states of surficial [28]. The higher Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio on the surface appears in the CuMnSm/Ce, promoting the dissociation and activation of surface oxygen species caused by more unsaturated chemical bonds and surface oxygen defects [29]. As shown in Fig. 3b, Cu 2p profiles show peaks near 933.5 eV for Cu 2p3/2, belonging to the XPS characteristics of Cu2+ and Cu+ [30]. The typical shake-up satellite emerges at 940–945 eV region in Cu 2p spectrum, confirming the identification of CuO. To further compare Cu+ with Cu2+, Cu LMM Auger electron spectra are depicted in Fig. S1b. From Table 2, it could be seen that the contents of Cu2+ and Cu+ show little difference between all samples and the values of Cu+/Cu2+ stay around 0.53. These phenomena mean that both Cu+ and Cu2+ are present at the surface and act as active sites. In Fig. 3c, three peaks of Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ on the surface are found at around 640.4, 641.5 and 642.7 eV in turn [31], and it can be determined that the order of higher value state species (Mn3+ and Mn4+) follows CuMnR/Ce> CuMn/Ce. Meanwhile, the difference between Mn 3s doublet peaks (ΔE, Fig. S1c) of each CuMnR/Ce catalyst is about 5.45 eV, which means Mn3+ is the most likely existing form. While, the ΔE of CuMn/Ce is 5.75 eV, indicating a higher ratio of Mn2+/Mn. For Mn species, the Mn3+ can promote the electronic transfer between copper and manganese oxide through Cu2++Mn3+ ⟷ Cu++Mn4+ and the generation of oxygen vacancies [23]. And Mn4+ is easily reduced and then enhances the redox property of the catalyst [13]. The higher ratio of Mn3+ relevant to oxygen vacancies in the CuMnR/Ce can be determined. To avoid disturbing the analysis of oxygen species, C 1s spectra were used to make an initial decision about the presence of carbonates species. Fig. S1d illustrates that the peak at 289.3–288.5 eV in C 1s spectra should be ascribed to carbonates [32]. Therefore, the XPS spectra of O 1s can be deconvoluted into three peaks, which correspond to the lattice oxygen (OL), active oxygen adsorbed at surface oxygen vacancies (OA), and surface-chemisorbed carbonates (OC), respectively (Fig. 3d) [33]. It could be seen that the relative contents of OA according to the area of relevant peak after deconvolution get higher after doping of rare earth metals on ceria. The ratio of OA/OL obeys the order of CuMnSm/Ce> CuMnHo/Ce> CuMnLa/Ce> CuMn/Ce, suggesting that the doping of R promoters into ceria lattices produces more surface oxygen vacancies as widely accepted [34]. This is in accordance with the analysis of XPS Ce 3d. From Fig. 4a, H2-TPR curves are shown to obtain different reduction characteristics of catalysts. Compared with the pure oxides (CuOx, MnOx and CeOx) that have been reported [31,35], the reduction peaks of CuMn/Ce shift towards rather lower temperatures (210–240 °C), implying better reducibility because of a synergistic effect of Cu–Mn oxides and a promoting interaction of the transition metal oxide and CeO2 [36]. Therefore, the overlapping peaks of their reductions are difficult to distinguish. The H2 consumption is mainly derived from four steps (labeled as I, II, III and Ⅳ) [37]. As shown in Fig. S2, the step I is associated with oxygen species easily reduced at lower temperatures related to the catalyst structure (177 °C); Step II includes the reduction process of Cu2+→Cu+→Cu0 and the Mn4+ reduction to Mn3+ (214 °C); Step III is attributed to Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and surface CeO2 to Ce2O3 (245 °C); The step Ⅳ is ascribed to Mn3O4 to MnO and the bulk CeO2 reduction (473 °C). As for reduction peaks in CuMnR/Ce possessing similar contributors to CuMn/Ce, the order of magnitude of the shift to high temperature is CuMnSm/Ce< CuMnHo/Ce< CuMnLa/Ce. Combined SEM, it shows that there are relatively less highly dispersed CuO particles on CuMnLa/Ce, which is the reason for poor reducibility. It can be inferred that La may weaken the interactions of CuOx and MnOx or transition metal oxide and CeO2. Conversely, Sm and Ho could play a positive role in promoting the synergistic effects between these metal ions in reduction processes. Moreover, it is noted that the onset temperature of H2 consumption is in the range from 110 to 210 °C ( Fig. 4b), following the sequence of CuMn/Ce< CuMnSm/Ce< CuMnHo/Ce< CuMnLa/Ce. The range is related to the reduction of reactive oxygen species (Step I), especially oxygen vacancies [7,36], which is also an indication of redox properties of the catalysts during the CO oxidation reaction associated with the onset of hydrogen consumption. The catalytic activity of catalysts will be affected by the contents of active components or the types of promotors, which can be assessed based on the temperature for 50% CO conversion (T50). According to the CO conversion curves in Fig. 5a, the T50 of CO oxidation over all catalysts can be recorded and shown in Fig. 5b. The CuMn/Ce exhibits higher catalytic activity with the lowest T50 (95.1 °C) for CO oxidation than the CuMnR/Ce catalysts (T50 = 140.2–160.3 °C). Notably, the area values of H2-TPR peaks of prepared samples exhibit the ascending order: CuMn/Ce>CuMnSm/Ce>CuMnHo/Ce>CuMnLa/Ce, which coincides with the decreasing order of T50 values for CO oxidation catalyzed by the samples (Fig. 5b). It can be found that the reduced reducibility can deteriorate the catalytic oxidation of CO and reflect the weakened interactions of copper, manganese and cerium ions. On the other hand, it could be presumed that the reason why the H2 is less consumed in CuMnR/Ce is the existence of these transition metal oxides and R oxides interactions and the poor dispersion of active species (Cu and Mn oxides) on the ceria support therefrom [33]. Among CuMnR/Ce catalysts, the CuMnSm/Ce shows a relatively excellent performance, which is consistent with the analysis with the XPS and H2-TPR. 3.2 Effect of Dry powder on the catalytic performance of CuMn/Ce To explore the influence of NH4H2PO4 on the CO oxidation performance of catalysts, the CuMn/Ce with different NH4H2PO4 mass ratios labeled as CuMn/Ce:P has been tested under the same experimental condition as the preceding catalytic activity test. When the CuMn/Ce:P is equal to 5:1–5:3, the catalyst activity exhibits no significant difference with the activity of pure CuMn/Ce and T50 is almost constant at around 93 °C. For the CuMn/Ce:P of 5:5, the curve of CO conversion a bit shifts to a higher temperature region, and the T50 (99.1 °C) increases by 4 °C ( Fig. 6a). Meanwhile, the SEM images at higher magnification in Fig. 5b,c show the distribution of used CuMn/Ce:P (5:5). The NH4H2PO4 (P) acts as the base material and CuMn/Ce particles accumulate on its surface randomly, forming the combination of NH4H2PO4 and CuMn/Ce. Further, the EDS mapping images of used CuMn/Ce:P of 5:5 after catalytic activity measurement are presented in Fig. 7a-f, where the Ce, O, Mn and Cu elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of the bulk NH4H2PO4. Therefore, the reason why the catalytic activity of CuMn/Ce:P of 5:5 is relatively poor may be that the caking of NH4H2PO4 due to the strong attraction between its particles leads to form the large lumps whose surface is adhered by plentiful CuMn/Ce particles [38]. As a result, pore blocking and surface masking belonging to the physical mechanism appear on the supported CuMn/Ce [20], inhibiting the reactivity of CO catalytic oxidation partially. The CO oxidation performance of CuMn/Ce catalyst mixed by NaHCO3 is analyzed through a series of experiments at different heating rates and with different NaHCO3 mass ratios (CuMn/Ce: Na). In Fig. 8a, the experimental results of different heating rates from 3 to 15 °C/min have a certain difference for pure CuMn/Ce, that is, the smaller the heating rate, the faster the reaction and the fuller the reaction. However, the catalytic performance of the CuMn/Ce: Na (5:1) mixture at each heating rate is negatively affected, especially in the temperature range starting at about 120 °C. As shown in Fig. 8b, the CuMn/Ce: Na (5:1) mixture heated at 6 °C/min performs the lowest CO conversion at 120 °C, which means the condition of heating rate causes the most severe poisoning effect by NaHCO3. As reported in the literature [39], the NaHCO3 in the N2 atmosphere will decompose and release CO2 and H2O at 100–180 °C, which can be illustrated in Eq. (1). (1) 2 NaHC O 3 ( s ) ⟶ Na 2 C O 3 ( s ) + C O 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) The dependence of mass ratios of CuMnCe and NaHCO3 (CuMn/Ce: Na) on the catalytic performance of CO oxidation is also investigated next. As depicted in Fig. 8c, the curves of CO oxidation are almost superimposable in CuMn/Ce: Na= 5:1 and 5:3, so do curves in CuMn/Ce: Na= 5:5 and 5:7. As can be noticed, the stagnating stage at which the CO conversion stops rising with temperature exists over a temperature range between 117 and 136 °C for CuMn/Ce: Na= 5:1 and 5:3 and between 144 and 178 ℃ for CuMn/Ce: Na= 5:5 and 5:7. Moreover, the temperature for 50% (T50) and 100% (T100) CO conversion varying with CuMn/Ce: Na are plotted in Fig. 8d, showing that the change of T100 is greater than that of T50 because of the increasing decomposition degree at T100. The EDS mapping images of CuMn/Ce: Na (5:1) after catalytic activity measurement (Fig. 8a-f) demonstrate two particles with different distributions of Na and Ce, where the major component is Na2CO3 in Fig. 9a-c but the main body is the CuMn/Ce catalyst in Fig. 9d-f. This phenomenon means that there is no severe adhesive attraction between CuMn/Ce catalyst and Na2CO3. For estimating the effect of Na2CO3, the experiments on the effect of Na2CO3 mass on CO oxidation performance of CuMn/Ce catalyst were carried out. The change of T50 and T100 values with the increase of mass can be ignored (Fig. S3), meaning that the production of Na2CO3 is almost no contribution to the inhibiting effect of NaHCO3. According to the literature [19,40], the presence of CO2 or H2O will cause the generation of inactive species on the surface of metal oxides. The concentrated release of CO2 could form adsorbed carbonate groups, bringing a limitation in the redox promotion by Cu/Mn oxides and CeO2 interactions for CO oxidation. And as the poisoning species, H2O will induce the formation of surface OH and then bicarbonates on metal oxides, decreasing the reactivity of metal oxides and blocking the active sites. On the other hand, CO2 will be more inclined to compete with CO to adsorb on the catalytic surface than H2O. Presumably, CO2 may act as a more critical role than H2O for the inhibiting effect of NaHCO3 on the catalytic CO oxidation. Based on the above analysis, the inhibiting effect of DPFEA on CO oxidation of CuMn/Ce is explained as shown in Fig. 10. The CO catalytic activities mixed by NaHCO3 impurity are worse than those mixed by NH4H2PO4 at the same mixing ratios. The caking of NH4H2PO4 due to the strong attraction between its particles leads to the large lumps whose surface has plentiful CuMn/Ce particles, covering certain adsorption sites of CO and O2. But there was no significant change in the scope of the experiment. In contrast, the most inhibiting effect of NaHCO3 is reduced by the concentrated and simultaneous release of CO2 and H2O rather than the adhesion between CuMn/Ce catalyst and Na2CO3. 3.3 Dry powder resistance of the catalysts The NaHCO3 resistance of ceria-supported Cu–Mn oxides catalyst is studied from both sides of rare metal dopants (R) and alkaline sorbent, in view of the inhibiting effect of NH4H2PO4 is not notable. The prepared catalysts and NaHCO3 mixed at a 5:1 mass ratio, and the CO oxidation performances of the mixtures versus temperature at 6 °C/min are drawn in Fig. 11a. Notably, the CO conversion rates versus temperature slow down significantly at 165–175 °C over all catalysts. Different from CuMn/Ce, CO oxidation on CuMnR/Ce shows no stagnating phase. The CO conversion curves of CuMnR/Ce have a common characteristic that when the CO conversion reaches nearly 40%, the CO conversion with temperature increases faster than before, implying the competition between NaHCO3 pyrolysis and CO oxidation shifts. The CO conversion of CuMnSm/Ce mixed with NaHCO3 is the first to reach 100% compared with CuMnHo/Ce and CuMnLa/Ce. To reveal the kinetic performances of the catalytic processes at the initial range of CO conversion, Arrhenius plots are presented in Fig. 11b and the activation energies (Ea) can be calculated by the slopes of the fitting curves. The order of Ea for pure catalysts is as follows: CuMnSm/Ce (42 kJ/mol)< CuMnLa/Ce (49 kJ/mol)< CuMnHo/Ce (58 kJ/mol)< CuMn/Ce (75 kJ/mol). When the NaHCO3 is mixed in them, the change of Ea of CuMn/Ce, CuMnSm/Ce or CuMnHo/Ce can be ignored. But the Ea of CuMnLa/Ce rises to 60 kJ/mol, which can be explained by the higher temperature at the lower CO conversion over CuMnLa/Ce, increasing the potential barrier by NaHCO3 decomposition. CO catalytic oxidation of CuMn/Ce coupled with LiOH as the CO2 sorbent under mixing with NaHCO3 was tested. Fig. 12a shows the CO conversion versus temperature of various LiOH weight percentages of LiOH-CuMn/Ce. It can be seen, the CO conversion curve of 20%LiOH-CuMn/Ce almost coincides with that of pure CuMn/Ce before the CO conversion reaches 84% of them. The temperature of 84% CO conversion (T84) and the CO conversion value at 120 °C of each LiOH-CuMn/Ce are presented in Fig. 12b. Meanwhile, the parameters of pure CuMn/Ce without NaHCO3 matching the 0% nominal percentage of LiOH were also included in Fig. 12b. These results further demonstrate the order of catalytic performance follows pure CuMn/Ce> 20%LiOH-CuMn/Ce> 30%LiOH-CuMn/Ce> 10%LiOH-CuMn/Ce> 50%LiOH-CuMn/Ce> 70%LiOH-CuMn/Ce. Particularly, the catalytic activity of 70%LiOH-CuMn/Ce is worse than that of the CuMn/Ce: Na (5:1) without LiOH, which may be attributed to the less catalyst surface area caused by superfluous lithium hydroxide and its carbonated product [22]. Hence, the appropriate amount of LiOH addition for the CO oxidation property and CO2 and H2O absorbing capacity is 20%, while the higher addition of LiOH will have a reverse effect. 4 Conclusions The supported copper-manganese-cerium composite catalyst (CuMn/Ce) synthesized through the wet impregnation method was tested for CO removal in loose contact with NH4H2PO4 or NaHCO3 as the typical dry powder fire extinguishing agent (DPFEA). The CO catalytic performance of the prepared samples was measured using a fixed bed reactor in the absence or presence of DPFEA impurities. Finally, approaches were proposed to address the inhibition of CO Oxidation in the presence of the DPFEA using the rare earth metal dopants (R=La, Sm and Ho) or an alkaline sorbent (LiOH). The caking of NH4H2PO4 due to the strong attraction between its particles leads to the large lumps whose surface has plentiful CuMn/Ce particles, covering the adsorption sites of CO and O2. In contrast, the most inhibiting effect of NaHCO3 is reduced by the concentrated release of carbon dioxide and water and the generation of inactive species on the surface of metal oxides rather than the adhesion between CuMn/Ce catalyst and Na2CO3. The CO catalytic activities mixed by NaHCO3 impurity are worse than those mixed by NH4H2PO4 at the same mixing ratios. Among CuMnR/Ce catalysts, CuMnSm/Ce is most appropriate for catalytic oxidation of CO in the presence of NaHCO3 impurity. For the 10–70 wt% LiOH coupled with CuMn/Ce, the best catalytic activity was found in 20 wt%LiOH-CuMn/Ce due to the synergistic interaction between CO2 and H2O absorbing capacity and coupling mass ratio. coredata.dc:description: The effects of typical dry powder fire extinguishing agents (DPFEA) on the CO oxidation catalysts were carried out. Cu-Mn-Ce-O composite catalyst (CuMn/Ce) for CO oxidation in loose contact with two typical components of DPFEA (NH4H2PO4 and NaHCO3) was tested to evaluate the performance of CO removal. The CO catalytic activities mixed by NaHCO3 are worse than those mixed by NH4H2PO4 at the same mixing ratios, which may be caused by the lower temperature range of NaHCO3 decomposition and the masked catalyst surfaces by CO2 and H2O released by NaHCO3. Further, the NaHCO3 resistance approach was proposed by introducing rare earth metal dopants (La, Sm and Ho) or coupling an alkaline sorbent (LiOH). Among all rare earth metal dopants, Sm is most appropriate for enhanced NaHCO3 resistance of CuMn/Ce catalyst. And 20 wt% LiOH-CuMn/Ce shows the best capacity for NaHCO3 resistance, as evidenced by the excellent CO catalytic performance similar to pure CuMn/Ce.
coredata.dc:title: Inhibition of CO oxidation over Cu-Mn-Ce-O composite catalyst in the presence of dry powder fire extinguishing agent: Mechanism investigation and mitigation strategy
